author: ceo
title: Decentralized Physics Tokenomics
description: Physics simulations run on centralized servers due to lack of decentralized infrastructure for academic & industry collaboration & use-cases

f6_assessments.q0:
Simulations are indeed playing an increasingly important role and the data generated from them are unfortunately mostly not publicly available and cannot be used by other teams. This hinders progress.

If the team manages to implement their idea, on the one hand more data would be available, on the other hand more computing power would be available for simulations, should a community be found to make it available.

If this succeeds, the project would strengthen industrial and scientific partnerships, which would definitely be an advantage for Cardano.

I think the project is still in its infancy and is highly complex. In addition, I do not completely understand from the proposal how the system is supposed to work. Therefore "only" four stars.
f6_assessments.q1:
The team is very small and the challenge is great. However, the proposal first deals with a proof of concept, which can definitely be set up by a small team. 

The proximity of the team and the qualifications definitely fit the task profile of the challenge. 

Due to the small team, the budget is also chosen accordingly and planned realistically.

The schedule seems a bit vague to me, but this is normal in such an early status of such a project.

All in all, the success of the project is not certain, but this is due to the nature of the project and not the team.
f6_assessments.q2: On the project's website you can find precise target parameters against which the project can be evaluated. Furthermore, milestones are defined which can help to classify the progress. However, it is not entirely clear how the community can evaluate the progress of the project. Clear communication would be very important.

f6_assessments.q0: The problem reported here is "physics simulations run on centralized servers due to lack of decentralized infrastructure for academic & industry collaboration & use-cases". And the solution to this problem is integrate basic tokenomic features into the developing computational infrastructure. In general, the Impact section is presented pretty clearly and coherently. In the proposed solution, the author provided us with an overview of the project. Then, the given objectives and goals are also clearly defined ("create the correct infrastructure to incentive mass adoption of cardano-based protocols in the computationally oriented scientific communities including academia, industry, start-ups, and individual community members"). The target audience as well as which industry that could be benefic are also clearly outlined. In addition, the proposer described the challenges that will be encountered and has a clear plan to deal with them. At the same time, the proposal also demonstrated the impact of the project on Cardano, which could attract more users if implemented in the future. Thereby, I highly appreciate this author's presentation, very detailed, clear and apparent. My rating for this part is 5.
f6_assessments.q1:
"For this section, I would like to have a few reviews and comments as follows:
-First, in terms of time, this part of the proposal should be described the work they are expected to implement in bullet points. Likewise, I suggest that this section should be a bit more detailed about their timelines and milestones. Instead of provide the information about which task will be done after one to two month, you could make a smaller allocation such as specific days or what week to spend on which task. Remember to give an explicit schedule for the project. Proposal must show a reasonable plan not only in terms of what they will accomplish, but also how it needs to be accomplished.
- Second, about the budget, it is disappointing that the budget is not well defined in financial statements. A detailed budget allocation would increase the credibility of the proposal, so my advice for this section is that proposer should go into details of the budget for each work item. For instance: How much will it cost to hire employees? How do the team members will be paid, time-based (month / week / hour) or the amount of work they are in charge of? How long will they hire those people? Will there be any rental costs or other payments required? These things I have not seen the author mentioned.
- Third, regarding to team members, the proposal only describes two key team members. Many descriptions of these people are given, what they are capable of, what their experience is. And of course, I feel these people are quite trustworthy when there are links to their information and biographies. This makes it easier for the community to verify the identities and abilities of these people. However, the proposal would be better if it could mention the total number of team members, who were included and what positions were still needed. Similarly, what job they will take on. These ideas will make the proposal more detailed and clear.
"
f6_assessments.q2: Long-term and short-term goals are carefully considered by the proposer. The time period to cover all the goals is within 3-5 years, which is not a short period of time. Therefore, if these goals are analyzed more carefully and given a roadmap for completion, it will make it easier for the community to follow. Besides, KPIs are also given (Increased number of transactions on Cardano due to SingularityNET AI service calls.) consistent with the key metrics of the challenge, which is quite rare in the proposals. Also, at the end of the two months of funding, they will have prototypes to call specific computational algorithms, the number of CPUs, GPUs, and virtual nodes from the Cardano mainnet. The author has a strong vision for this project and the field in which he is engaged. I strongly agree that if this project is implemented, it will bring high results to the community. With the above comments, my rating is 5.

f6_assessments.q0:
(To set the record straight, I don’t pretend to know anything about physics. I can only evaluate the proposal by its merits.) Justin and the team had a proposal already in Fund7. They got enough votes but they were not funded. Now they are trying again with three different proposals. Their Decentralized Physics Simulations proposal for $28K is in the Miscellaneous Challenge (https://cardano.ideascale.com/c/idea/404576) and there’s another one for Decentralized AI Drug Development and $ 56K in the Business Solutions challenge (https://cardano.ideascale.com/c/idea/396820). It would be a good practice to cross-link related proposals.

The issue they have identified is that “centralized infrastructures are rather limiting in developing AI-centric frameworks for improving the efficiency and accuracy of physics computation and knowledge extraction”. They wish to create a Cardano-based decentralized alternative infrastructure to benefit the “academia, industry, start-ups, and individual community members”. Leveraging NuNet computational resources and SingularityNet for AI enhancements, their Hetzerk protocol will one day help in the simulation of physical systems, faster than many of today’s supercomputers. The scope of this proposal, however, is limited only to introducing basic tokenomics into the protocol by hiring a Plutus developer for two months. The protocol’s long-term impact may be mind-boggling, but its completion is expected only 3-5 years down the line. The impact of this proposal is quite limited.
f6_assessments.q1: It would be good for the team to have a marketing/sales/strategy oriented person involved to hone and simplify their communication. Now the proposal oscillates between the five-year vision and the immediate reality, making it difficult to estimate what is relevant right now. The budget is basically nothing but the developer’s salary cost and another $1,000 added for “consulting”. The plan doesn’t tell whether they have the Plutus developer in mind already or whether s/he needs to be recruited. Furthermore, it seems to be heavily dependent on NuNet’s success.
f6_assessments.q2: The plan is quite unclear. It says in the proposal that “our progress will be measured by integration of basic tokenomics into our platform”. Apart from that there is no analysis given how the community can stay updated whether the project is on track or not.

f6_assessments.q0: I loved this idea, it's about taking to Cardano's blockchain the various ifnromations linked to the world of simulation (which is used in various types of industry, as exemplified by the proponent in the case of molecular simulations that involved studies during the Covid 19 pandemic ). The proponent states very well what the problem is, for example, that after the simulations are carried out, all the information is stored in an impractical and antiquated way, and if they were minted on the Cardano blockchain, in addition to being incorruptible, it would also be possible that a much larger amount of information was recorded and stored. In fact, it is a very interesting use case that takes advantage of the cryptographic universe very well, I found the idea very promising, being able to bring a new type of audience (companies, groups of scientists and etc that are interested in simulation) to our blockchain . With this, the objectives of the challenge of expanding Cardano would be fully achieved. The target markets - Biotechnology, Artificial Intelligence, Chemical Synthesis - are growing, that is, we have the possibility of reaching more and more people from this project. In my view, the potential for a lot of impact is high.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal does not have an exact roadmap. Partial results are given for the first 2 months, but what activities would be necessary for these goals to be achieved? I don't think the proponent explains the development process well, he exposes the results facet but not what's behind it. As a result, we were unable to understand well what the work routine of the professionals would be like and what small actions they would be developing. Regarding the money, I also think it is poorly explained. The asking amount ($8,000) is split into two parts - the developer's salary and possible miscellaneous fees (what, for example?). The proponent writes "Blockchain Development (Plutus) 2 1 $3,500 $7,000". What does this 2 1 mean? This part is a little confusing. Finally, speaking of the team, we have two people involved, one of whom provides a much deeper detail about himself and his resume (Justin Diamond) than the other. It would be ideal for both to explain about their careers with the same level of specificity. There is a lot of trust in Justin, but not so much in Floriane since we have little information about it. Anyway, the topic is average.
f6_assessments.q2: The only thing the proponent says about measuring progress is that it would be done by integrating basic tokennomics into their platform. Other than that, quantitative or qualitative metrics are not traced to understand how the project would be developing. It is complicated to audit this proposal also due to the fact that it does not have a detailed roadmap. That is, in general, it is not traceable and measurable. It is necessary for the author to review this part, giving objective formalities for the Cardano community to monitor the progress of activities. When it comes to ultimate success, short and medium-term goals are said, we know better what to expect; I think it is necessary, however, that all this is easily accessible to the Cardano community. Would monthly meetings be held? Prepared reports that would be sent to the community through the communication channels already used? How would this information reach everyone (and in accessible language so that everyone could understand it equally?). I think auditability can and should improve, especially in the first part.

f6_assessments.q0: The proposal is aim at harnessing the power of decentralization through the development of free decentralized physics algorithmic computations using GPU and CPU processing power made possible by AI infrastructure provided on NuNet and SingularityNet on Cardano Network for the purpose of  harnessing this processing power for physic computational simulations, top research purposes, AI infrastructures, industrial purposes etc. This is obviously a much demanded service by industries and research organisation and of course leading to immense benefits in terms of increased adoption of Cardano Blockchain Network. The proposal seeks to achieve this goal by creating a platform for incentivizing all participants and/users' contribution with issuance of tokens on the Cardano Network. This is an awesome proposal that definitely fit into campaign objectives and should be overwhelmingly supported by the community.
f6_assessments.q1: The proposal has provided relevant information as regards, the plans and modalities and requirements to achieve the set objectives. The team behind the proposal is well versed in the field with the required skill and competence to deliver the project. The Budget break down and cost analysis seem reasonable and achievable within the stipulated timeframe. It should be noted that there is need to contemplate the possibility of engaging relevant partnerships and collaborations.
f6_assessments.q2: The proposal has provided relevant information on what to look forward to, the set goal and objectives and the basis to monitor and assess to the project's progress and development however there are no quantifiable success metrics coupled with the fact that no specific roadmap and timelines were provided. Despite this variance, I can reasonably affirm the information is more than enough to verify the success of the project.

solution: To allow free decentralized physics computations we will integrate basic tokenomic features into our developing computational infrastructure
experience: Justin Diamond - PhD Candidate - AI Researcher in Physics, Chemistry, Pharma, Bioinformatics at academic institutions including University of Michigan, Toyota Technological Institute of Chicago, Boston University, University of Luxembourg, and University of Basel.
